<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 306, 304, 320]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 328, 155, 342]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 306, 907, 360]]<|/det|>
9231/13 October/November 2018 3 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 370, 418, 385]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 392, 468, 406]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF10)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 390, 434]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 448, 785, 463]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 464, 328, 477]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 479, 504, 493]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 494, 504, 508]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 509, 380, 523]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 538, 907, 567]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 568, 907, 597]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 598, 506, 612]]<|/det|>
The use of a calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 613, 907, 641]]<|/det|>
Results obtained solely from a graphic calculator, without supporting working or reasoning, will not receive credit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 643, 607, 657]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 672, 607, 686]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 688, 755, 702]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 95, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 467, 93]]<|/det|>
The vectors \(\mathbf{a}\) , \(\mathbf{b}\) , \(\mathbf{c}\) and \(\mathbf{d}\) in \(\mathbb{R}^{3}\) are given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 100, 718, 145]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{a} = \left( \begin{array}{c}1\\ 2\\ 1 \end{array} \right),\quad \mathbf{b} = \left( \begin{array}{c}2\\ 9\\ 0 \end{array} \right),\quad \mathbf{c} = \left( \begin{array}{c}3\\ 3\\ 4 \end{array} \right)\quad \mathrm{and}\quad \mathbf{d} = \left( \begin{array}{c}0\\ -8\\ 3 \end{array} \right).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 168, 156, 186]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 168, 448, 186]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\{\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}, \mathbf{c}\}\) is a basis for \(\mathbb{R}^{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 170, 920, 187]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 198, 920, 616]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 638, 154, 656]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 638, 420, 656]]<|/det|>
Express \(\mathbf{d}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\) , \(\mathbf{b}\) and \(\mathbf{c}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 640, 920, 657]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 670, 920, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 771, 94]]<|/det|>
The sequence of positive numbers \(u_{1}\) , \(u_{2}\) , \(u_{3}\) , … is such that \(u_{1} < 3\) and, for \(n \geqslant 1\) ,

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 102, 564, 136]]<|/det|>
\[u_{n + 1} = \frac{4u_{n} + 9}{u_{n} + 4}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 159, 156, 177]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 158, 918, 191]]<|/det|>
By considering \(3 - u_{n + 1}\) , or otherwise, prove by mathematical induction that \(u_{n} < 3\) for all positive integers \(n\). [5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 205, 920, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 410, 92]]<|/det|>
A curve is defined parametrically by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 101, 630, 122]]<|/det|>
\[x = t - \frac{1}{2}\sin 2t\quad \mathrm{and}\quad y = \sin^2 t.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 130, 918, 161]]<|/det|>
The arc of the curve joining the point where \(t = 0\) to the point where \(t = \pi\) is rotated through one complete revolution about the \(x\)-axis. The area of the surface generated is denoted by \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 176, 158, 192]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 176, 243, 191]]<|/det|>
Show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[424, 192, 575, 227]]<|/det|>
\[S = a\pi \int_{0}^{\pi}\sin^{3}t\mathrm{d}t,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 231, 444, 248]]<|/det|>
where the constant \(a\) is to be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 231, 920, 248]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 260, 920, 910]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 154, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 73, 678, 92]]<|/det|>
Using the result \(\sin 3t = 3 \sin t - 4 \sin^3 t\), find the exact value of \(S\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 920, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 75, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of the matrix \(\mathbf{A}\) with \(\mathbf{e}\) as a corresponding eigenvector, and \(\mu\) is an eigenvalue of the matrix \(\mathbf{B}\) for which \(\mathbf{e}\) is also a corresponding eigenvector.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 121, 156, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 121, 918, 139]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\lambda + \mu\) is an eigenvalue of the matrix \(\mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B}\) with \(\mathbf{e}\) as a corresponding eigenvector. [2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 153, 918, 401]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 428, 308, 445]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{A}\) , given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 447, 576, 498]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 2 & 3 \\ 1 & 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 503, 457, 551]]<|/det|>
has \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}, \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 4 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\) as eigenvectors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 565, 154, 583]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 565, 448, 581]]<|/det|>
Find the corresponding eigenvalues.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 565, 920, 583]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 598, 920, 910]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 326, 92]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 95, 565, 128]]<|/det|>
\[y = \frac{x^{2} + ax - 1}{x + 1},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 133, 361, 149]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) is constant and \(a > 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 164, 156, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 164, 497, 181]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 164, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 920, 680]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 700, 154, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 700, 473, 718]]<|/det|>
Show that \(C\) intersects the \(x\)-axis twice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 700, 920, 718]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 733, 920, 915]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 682, 92]]<|/det|>
Justifying your answer, find the number of stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 75, 920, 93]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 920, 490]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 514, 153, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 757, 532]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\) , stating the coordinates of its point of intersection with the \(y\) -axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 514, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 73, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 73, 460, 92]]<|/det|>
Use de Moivre's theorem to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 100, 725, 119]]<|/det|>
\[\sin 8\theta = 8\sin \theta \cos \theta (1 - 10\sin^2\theta +24\sin^4\theta -16\sin^6\theta). \quad [6]\]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 920, 920]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 334, 92]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\Pi_{1}\) has equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 95, 613, 141]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{r} = \left( \begin{array}{c}5\\ 1\\ 0 \end{array} \right) + s\left( \begin{array}{c} - 4\\ 1\\ 3 \end{array} \right) + t\left( \begin{array}{c}0\\ 1\\ 2 \end{array} \right).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 160, 154, 177]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 160, 415, 177]]<|/det|>
Find a cartesian equation of \(\Pi_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 160, 920, 177]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 191, 920, 545]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 566, 452, 584]]<|/det|>
<pre>The plane \(\Pi_{2}\) has equation \(3x + y - z = 3.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 599, 154, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 598, 733, 616]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between \(\Pi_{1}\) and \(\Pi_{2}\), giving your answer in degrees.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 598, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 631, 920, 915]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
Find an equation of the line of intersection of \(\varPi_{1}\) and \(\varPi_{2}\), giving your answer in the form \(\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{a} + \lambda \mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 92, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 123, 920, 923]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 371, 92]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 95, 555, 113]]<|/det|>
\[r = 5\sqrt{(\cot\theta)},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 120, 290, 138]]<|/det|>
where \(0.01 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 152, 154, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 152, 918, 185]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the finite region bounded by \(C\) and the line \(\theta = 0.01\), showing full working. Give your answer correct to 1 decimal place. [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 198, 920, 549]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 572, 440, 590]]<|/det|>
Let \(P\) be the point on \(C\) where \(\theta = 0.01\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 604, 154, 622]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 604, 920, 622]]<|/det|>
Find the distance of \(P\) from the initial line, giving your answer correct to 1 decimal place. [2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 636, 920, 918]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 153, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 588, 90]]<|/det|>
Find the maximum distance of \(C\) from the initial line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 73, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 106, 920, 590]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 610, 156, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 610, 241, 628]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 610, 920, 629]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 75, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 75, 591, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the particular solution of the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[383, 100, 613, 133]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}x}{\mathrm{d}t^{2}} +2\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t} +10x = 37\sin 3t,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 142, 475, 170]]<|/det|>
given that \(x = 3\) and \(\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t} = 0\) when \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 147, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 183, 920, 922]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 106, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 75, 524, 92]]<|/det|>

<label>EITHER</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 164, 570, 199]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}r = \textstyle {\frac{1}{2}}n(n + 1). \quad (3)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 75, 154, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 75, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
By considering \((2r + 1)^4 - (2r - 1)^4\), use the method of differences and the result given in part **(i)** to prove that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 112, 581, 148]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}r^{3} = \textstyle {\frac{1}{4}}n^{2}(n + 1)^{2}. \quad (5)\]
